title: 115_hr3179
content: The Act is titled the "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act". It includes a requirement for cost-benefit analysis for certain prudential regulations. The Act mandates that Federal banking agencies cannot impose stricter prudential regulations than international standards without publishing a rationale and cost-benefit analysis for public comment. The Act prohibits Federal banking agencies from implementing stricter prudential regulations without justification and cost-benefit analysis for public review, considering impacts on credit, liquidity, competitiveness, employment, economic growth, and monetary policy execution. The Act prohibits Federal banking agencies from implementing stricter prudential regulations without justification and cost-benefit analysis for public review. Otherwise, a prudential regulation must be repealed or amended through a public notice and comment process. The Act prohibits Federal banking agencies from implementing stricter prudential regulations without justification and cost-benefit analysis for public review. A lookback requirement is also imposed on final rules issued by Federal banking agencies after January 1, 2007, to analyze the incremental costs and benefits of superseded prudential regulations. The Act mandates that Federal banking agencies must issue a report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment, detailing the description and analysis of any prudential regulation that becomes superseded. Definitions for "appropriate Federal banking agency" are also provided in the section. The term "banking organization" refers to a depository institution or a depository institution holding company as defined in the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The term "corresponding international prudential standard" refers to an international standard on which a prudential regulation is based. Prudential regulation pertains to rules regarding capital, leverage, and liquidity requirements for banking organizations. It includes setting minimum requirements for capital, debt, and liquid assets relative to assets or cash flows. Prudential regulation implements international standards for banking organizations based on capital, leverage, debt, and liquidity measures. The "international prudential standard" refers to standards adopted by international institutions like the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and the Financial Stability Board, relating to capital, leverage, liquidity requirements for banking organizations. The term "superseded prudential regulation" refers to a regulation that addresses similar risks or achieves similar goals as an international standard.
